content.question: In a controlled experiment, engineers test a firecracker. The firecracker has mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and is placed at rest on a horizontal surface. When the firecracker is lit, it explodes and breaks apart into two pieces. In the first trial, one piece with mass <math alttext="the fraction m over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math> moves to the left with speed <math alttext="v sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and the other piece moves to the right with speed <math alttext="v sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. A second trial is performed with an identical firecracker, and one piece with mass <math alttext="the fraction 3 m over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math> moves to the left, again with speed <math alttext="v sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. What will the speed of the other piece be in this second trial?

<math alttext="the fraction 3 V sub R, end sub, over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>
